description: Governor Whitmer urges people to avoid non-essential travel and gatherings of >100 people
WHO declares COVID-19 to be a global pandemic
Governor Whitmer closes K-12 schools from March 16 - April 5
Governor Whitmer bans gatherings > 250 people
Governor Whitmer bans dine-in service at bars and restaurants, and gyms, movie theaters, and recreational venues closed.
Governor Whitmer bans gatherings > 50 people
First confirmed COVID-19 death in Wayne County
Governor Whitmer issues stay-at-home order barring non-essential in-person business, activities, and events through April 13
annotation: MI Gov issues stay-at-home order through 4/13

description: Governor Whitmer issues state disaster declaration, and asks lawmakers to extend emergency declaration for 70 days
Governor Whitmer orders K-12 schools closed for the rest of the school year
annotation: MI Gov closes K-12 schools indefinitely

description: Governor Whitmer urges residents to wear face masks in public
annotation: MI Gov urges all to wear masks in public

description: Governor Whitmer extends state's stay-at-home order until April 30
Governor Whitmer extends state's stay-at-home order until May 15 with some restrictions on outdoor activities lifted
Governor Whitmer, as part of MI Safe Start Plan, will allow for some types of work with very low infection risk, such as construction, real-estate, and traditionally outdoor work to resume May 7
annotation: MI Gov allows some low-risk work to resume 5/7

description: Governor Whitmer extends stay-at-home order through May 28, but allows provisions for some manufacturing to resume on May 11
Governor Whitmer extends stay-at-home order through May 28, but allows provisions for some manufacturing to resume on May 11

Governor Whitmer unveils plan to partially reopen business in the Upper Peninsula and 17 counties in the Northern Lower Peninsula starting May 22, reopening non-essential retail stores and restaurants for in-person dining (with a maximum of 50% capacity).
annotation: MI Gov plans to reopen U.P. 5/22

description: Heavy rains cause dam failure at the Edenville and Sanford Dams, forcing approximately 10,000 people to be evacuated from Midland, the village of Sanford, Edenville, Tittabawassee Township, Thomas Township, Saginaw Township, and the Dow Chemical plant.

Governor Whitmer signs executive order allowing gatherings of 10 people (or fewer), as long as participants practice social distancing behaviors. Additionally, starting May 29, non-essential health care services (medical, dental, and veterinary) can resume. Starting May 26, retail stores and auto dealerships can open for appointment only with a maximum capacity of 10 people at a time
annotation: MI Gov allows gatherings of â‰¤10

description: Governor Whitmer extends stay-at-home order through June 12, and state of emergency through June 19, mandating that venues like theaters, gyms and casinos remain closed

Governor Whitmer ends the state's Stay Home, Stay Safe order, effective immediately, indicating the state has moved into Phase 4 of Michigan's Safe Start recovery plan, including permitting outdoor gatherings of up to 100 people, office work, and reopening of outdoor parks and recreation facilities.
Governor Whitmer allows restaurants to reopen to in-person service, as long as they follow safe COVID-19 protocols.
Personal care services including hair salons, nail salons, massage businesses resume operations

Governor Whitmer requires the use of face coverings in crowded outdoor spaces, reiterates that individuals must wear masks when in indoor public spaces, and requires businesses to refuse entry or service to people who refuse to wear a face covering, with limited exceptions
